newsitem.title: UK: N.Irishman in court over London Docklands bomb.
newsitem.headline: N.Irishman in court over London Docklands bomb.

text.p: A man from Northern Ireland appeared in a top-security court in London on Saturday charged with a deadly bomb attack in the capital's Docklands district that ended the IRA's ceasefire in February 1996.

James McCardle, 29, was charged with two counts of murder and one of conspiracy to cause an explosion. He was remanded in custody until a full court hearing at which his lawyer said he would be denying the charges.
The Docklands bomb killed two people and marked the end of a 17-month ceasefire by Irish Republican Army guerrillas fighting to end British rule of Northern Ireland.
Police are already holding another Northern Ireland man in custody over the attack.
Security sources in Northern Ireland said McCardle was among seven people arrested a week ago in a raid on a farmhouse near Crosmaglen in Northern Ireland.

McCardle made his brief court appearance a day after two small explosions and a series of suspected IRA bomb warnings paralysed rail and road traffic in northern England in what appeared to be the latest attempt by the guerrillas to disrupt Britain's May 1 election campaign.

Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary Sir Patrick Mayhew on Saturday condemned the perpetrators as thugs and criminals but said the campaign of disruption would not force Britain to "bend the knee to violence".
